Governing jurisdictions differ over the legality of the combined use of phenylbutazone (PBZ) and flunixin meglumine (FM) in athletic horses. The objective of this experiment was to test the hypothesis that the combined use of FM and PBZ is more efficacious than a narcotic (NARC).Eight adult TB horses shod unilaterally with adjustable heart bar shoes were studied over a 2-week period. Non-weight bearing lameness was induced with tightening of the shoe. One hr later, horses received 1 of 2 treatments: PBZ (4.4 mg/kg IV) and FM (1.1 mg/kg IV), or meperidine HCl (1 mg/kg IM). Meperidine was administered IM to avoid the common excitatory side-effects of IV narcotic administration in horses. Responses (HR and lameness score (LS) determined blindly) were recorded at 20-min intervals for 1 hr prior to and another 12 hrs after drug administration. One week later, treatment assignments were reversed and the experiment was repeated. Data were analyzed using RMANOVA and Tukey's test post hoc with P,0.05 considered significant.HR and LS were lower in NARC trials from 2.3 through 3.6 hrs postadministration (P,0.05). In PBZ+FM trials, HR and LS were lower from 1 through 12 hrs (P,0.05) and were lower earlier and longer than NARC (P,0.05). It was concluded that the combination of PBZ+FM was considerably more effective in alleviating lameness than a narcotic universally-prohibited during competition. An association between calcium activated chloride channel 1 (CLCA1), epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), mucin 5AC (MUC5AC), B-cell lymphoma 2 (Bcl-2), interleukin (IL)-13, interferon (IFN)-c and mucus hyperproduction has been reported in airways of patients with human asthma and/or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) as well as in animal models of these diseases. Therefore, we chose to analyse the expression of these genes in horses with inflammatory airway disease (IAD) and recurrent airway obstruction (RAO). Cells of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) and epithelial brushings (BR) from 11 clinically healthy, 7 IAD-and 12 RAO-affected horses were analysed by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Further, we compared mRNA levels of these genes in BALF and brushing samples from 7 of the 12 RAO-affected horses before and after allergen challenge.

In BALF samples, IL-13 was significantly decreased in horses with RAO compared to their healthy counterparts (p , 0.05). Furthermore, IL-13 expression decreased in RAO-affected horses after hay challenge (p 5 0.03). None of the other genes showed significant differences either between groups or after hay challenge of RAO horses. IAD-affected horses showed very similar, but less pronounced results.Since intratracheal mucus accumulation increased significantly (p 5 0.01) with disease severity, our results suggest that mucus production in equine IAD and RAO are induced by pathways that are independent of IL-13, CLCA1, EGFR, MUC5AC and Bcl-2 mRNA levels. West Nile virus (WNV) is a single stranded, enveloped RNA virus capable of causing encephalitic disease in horses. Unvaccinated horses are at risk for developing WNV disease in endemic geographic regions. Effective vaccination reduces disease frequency in horses and diminishes disease severity in vaccinated individuals that become infected with WNV. Recent data indicate CD4+ lymphocytes are required for effective protection against disease, in particular, cross talk between CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocytes must be functional. The objective of this project was to investigate immune responses in horses throughout a series of 3 vaccinations using a commercial inactivated vaccine.

Immune responses to vaccination were determined by neutralizing antibody titers with plaque reduction neutralization test (PRNT), IgM titer (capture ELISA), WNV specific antibody Ig subclass responses, WNVThe purpose of this report is: 1) define the molecular species of MMP 9 released by bovine neutrophils (PMN); 2) demonstrate PMN MMP 9 released in vitro is complexed with haptoglobin (Hp); 3) describe Hp-MMP 9 complexes in sera of septic cattle.Isolated peripheral blood PMN were incubated with phorbol esters for 30 minutes. Conditioned media (CM) were harvested and frozen. Serum was obtained from cattle with confirmed: acute sepsis (peritonitis n54; septic myositis n51); chronic lung abscess (n51); chronic mastitis (n51), and sera from healthy animals (routine Johnes' surveillance). Concentrated PMN CM and serum proteins were subjected to affinity chromatography to purify Hp-MMP 9 complexes. Fractions containing MMP 9 monomer (105 kDa), dimer (210 kDa) and high molecular mass gelatinolytic complexes (.300 kDa-1000 kDa) were analyzed by SDS-PAGE. High molecular mass gelatinolytic complexes upon reduction are converted to: MMP 9 monomer (105 kDa), b-Hp (38 kDa) and a-Hp (15-18 kDa). Peptide analysis of proteins confirm identity. These complexes retain the functional properties of each constituent protein (bind hemoglobin, protease activity).Hp-MMP 9 complexes are present in the sera of septic cattle, but not chronically ill or healthy animals. These complexes may prove useful as a marker of neutrophil activation and be indicative of sepsis. The purpose of this report is: 1) to define neutrophil accumulation after intra-bronchial LPS; 2) Characterize the effects of matrix metalloproteinase inhibition on LPS induced lung inflammation.Holstein bull calves (21-35 days of age), were fed milk re-placer and administered LPS intrabronchially (LPS; n 5 8) or an MMP inhibitor (n56) prior to intrabronchial LPS. The MMP inhibitor (HMR 1035; 15 mg/kg) was added to milk re-placer 12 h before LPS and immediately after recovery from anesthesia. The calves were anesthetized and a broncho-alveolar lavage catheter was placed, (location determined by radiography) and 2.34 mg M. hemolytica LPS/kg body weight in 20 mL of sterile saline was infused. The calves were re-anesthetized for BAL and euthanized for necropsy 24 h later. The trachea was cannulated for formalin fixation in situ (25 cm H 2 O). After fixation, lung tissue sections were acquired. Tissues were embedded in paraffin and sectioned for H&E and immunohistochemistry (IHC) of MMP 9 expression.LPS infusion produced neutrophil influx, macrophage accumulation, hemorrhage and tissue injury. This was localized to the region served by the bronchus infused with LPS. Immunohistochemically, there was marked increases in MMP 9 within macrophages. Few PMN were positive for MMP 9 by IHC suggesting degranulation during the process of transmigration. Calves receiving the MMP inhibitor prior to LPS had minimal changes in their lungs in terms of tissue morphology and IHC. Matrix metalloproteinases appear to play a role in PMN transmigration and influx in LPS injured calf lung. Condensed tannins are secondary plant metabolites able reducing the burden of gastro-intestinal parasites in ruminants by direct anthelmintic effects or indirect effects inducing an enhanced immune response. Several studies have demonstrated that orally administrated Quebracho extracts reduce faecal egg counts (FEC) and total worm burden in experimentally infected sheep and goats. The aim of this study was to investigate whether orally administrated Quebracho extracts had anthelmintic effects in naturally infected grazing lambs.Thirty-six non-weaned French Texel lambs were investigated six weeks after start of the grazing period (T6). They were divided in three homogenous groups of similar body weight, FEC, gender and parity. Group 1 (n512) was treated at T6 and T10 with orally administrated moxidectin (0.2 mg/kg), group 2 (n512) was placebo-treated (50 ml of H2O) and group 3 was treated at T6 with a single dose of dissolved Quebraco extract (1 mg/ kg) and was treated at T10 with two doses of Quebraco extract (1 mg/kg) that were administrated 24 h apart. Body weight and faecal egg count were determined 6 (T6), 7 (T7), 10 (T10), 11 (T11) and 14 (T14) weeks after start of the grazing period. Parasitological analysis was performed using the McMaster technique in order to establish a FEC. Separate counts and scores were established for nematodes, Moniezia expansa and Eimeria spp. Data are shown as means 6 SE; statistical analysis was performed after logtransformation for variance stabilization.No differences of bodyweight were recorded between groups throughout the investigation period (T6: 9.360.8 kg versus T14: 28.661.7 kg, p,0.001). Eimeria spp infestation significantly decreased over time (T6: 3300069700 eggs/g feces versus T14: 7006270 eggs/g feces, p,0.001), treatment-related differences were not detected. Moniezia expansa infestation was non detectable at T6 and was maximal at T10 (4006200 eggs/g feces); treatment-related differences were not detected. Nematode infestation included Trichostrongyloïdes, Chabertia, Nematodirus and Trichostrongylus. Given the low infestation, a collective count of nematodes was performed. Infestation remained stable in placebo-and Quebracho-treated groups throughout the investigation period (T6: 320696 eggs/g feces versus T14: 4206115 eggs/g feces, NS), whereas a significant decrease of FEC was recorded at T7, T10, T11 and T14 in moxidectin-treated lambs (T6: 4506116 eggs/g feces versus T7: 27619; T10: 90663; T11: 969; T14: 63639 eggs/g feces, p,0.01).This field study suggests that a single or double oral administration of Quebracho extracts at the dose of 1 mg/kg does not exert an anthelmintic effect in naturally infected grazing lambs. No adverse effects of tannin administration on bodyweight were noted and further studies could test whether other dose regimens or administration types are efficient under field conditions. Pepsinogen C (Pg C) is a minor proenzyme secreted primarily by the gastric mucosa. Under acidic conditions in the stomach, Pg C is activated to pepsin C, and participates in the digestion of dietary proteins. Like the major proenzyme, pepsinogen A (Pg A), Pg C can be found in the vascular space in measurable quantities. In humans, the ratio of serum concentrations of Pg A to Pg C is used as marker for specific gastrointestinal disorders such as gastritis, duodenal ulceration, gastric cancer, and Helicobacter pylori infection. In pigs, gastric ulceration is a worldwide problem and minimally-invasive diagnosis of gastric lesions would be of great value as early diagnosis may allow early intervention and lead to improved longevity of affected pigs. The overall goal of this project was to develop immunoassays for porcine pepsinogens A and C and to evaluate the utility of the ratio of Pg A / Pg C for the diagnosis of gastric ulcers in pigs. We recently developed an immunoassay for porcine pepsinogen A. However, there is no commercial source for either purified porcine Pg C or antiporcine Pg C antibodies. Therefore, the present research was undertaken to develop a protocol for the purification of porcine pepsinogen C that would allow the purification of ample quantities of pure Pg C for the development of a radioimmunoassay for the quantification of porcine Pg C in blood.

During the purification process, fractions containing pepsinogens were identified by means of measurement of proteolytic activity using a hemoglobin digestion assay. Gastric mucosa from pigs was homogenized and subjected to a series of purification steps: ammonium sulfate precipitation, weak anion-exchange chromatography on a diethylaminoethyl (DEAE) column, and strong anion-exchange chromatography on a Mono-Q column.
